title: Who Am I?
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: "And you have been made complete in Him, who is the head of all rule and authority."

content.heading: Introduction: The Crisis of Identity
paragraphs: Who am I?
This is one of the deepest questions every human being wrestles with. In today's world, people try to define themselves in countless ways...
...But Colossians 2:10 declares a powerful truth: 'You have been made complete in Him.'

content.heading: Point 1: The World Offers a False Identity
paragraphs: The world constantly tells us, 'Define yourself.'
It urges people to create their own identity based on feelings, performance, or culture. But this leads to confusion and instability...
...No earthly identity can satisfy the soul because we were not created to define ourselves—we were created to be defined by God.

content.heading: Point 2: Our Identity in Christ—Complete, Not Lacking
paragraphs: Colossians 2:10 says, 'You have been made complete in Him.'
What does it mean to be 'complete in Christ'?
1. We Lack Nothing for Salvation...
2. We Lack Nothing for Acceptance...
3. We Lack Nothing for Purpose...
4. We Lack Nothing for Security...
...The world says, 'Find yourself.' But God says, 'You are already complete in Christ.'

content.heading: Point 3: How the Gospel Makes This Possible
paragraphs: How do we become complete in Christ? Through the Gospel:
1. Christ Restores Our True Identity...
2. Christ Gives Us a New Name...
3. Christ Fulfills Our Deepest Longings...
4. Christ Replaces Our Self-Definition...
...Because of Christ, we no longer need to search for significance in anything else.

content.heading: Point 4: Living from Our Identity in Christ
paragraphs: If we are already complete in Christ, how should we live?
1. Stop Striving for Worth in Temporary Things...
2. Let Go of False Labels...
3. Find Satisfaction in Christ, Not Ministry...
4. Live with Boldness and Peace...
...We don't have to prove ourselves—we are already fully loved, fully accepted, and fully complete in Jesus.

content.heading: Application: Where Are You Finding Your Identity?
paragraphs: Are you trying to define yourself by success, ministry, or approval from others?
Are you looking to Christ alone, or are you searching for something more?
Do you truly believe you are complete in Him?
...True peace and purpose come when we stop looking to the world for identity and rest in who we are in Christ.

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: "Lord, I confess that I have often sought my identity in things that cannot satisfy. But Your Word says I am complete in Christ. Help me to rest in this truth and live from the identity You have given me. Amen."

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Take time today to write down all the ways you have defined yourself apart from Christ. Then, replace each one with what God says about you in Scripture (e.g., "I am loved," "I am forgiven," "I am complete in Him").

content.heading: Final Thought
paragraphs: The world says, 'You must create your identity.'
The Gospel says, 'Your identity is already complete in Christ.'
...Rest in Him—you lack nothing.

title: Seeking God Beyond Convenience
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: "You will seek me and find me when you seek me with all your heart."

content.heading: Introduction: A Faith of Convenience?
paragraphs: In a world filled with distractions, it is easy to make our time with God a matter of convenience rather than commitment.
We pray when we have time, but never make time.
We read Scripture when it fits into our schedule, but never schedule it.
We worship when we feel like it, but neglect it when life gets busy.
A relationship with God that is based on convenience will always be shallow, inconsistent, and powerless. True devotion is about seeking God with all our hearts, not just when it is easy.

content.heading: 1. Convenience Devotion vs. Costly Devotion
paragraphs: Many approach devotion with a mindset of minimal effort—fitting it into life's leftover moments. But Jesus calls us to a costly devotion.
### Convenience Devotion – Gives God time only when it is easy
* Prays only in emergencies.
* Reads the Bible without applying it.
* Attends church if nothing else is scheduled.
Costly Devotion – Seeks God above all else
* Prays persistently (Luke 18:1).
* Treasures God's Word daily (Psalm 1:2).
* Makes worship a priority (Hebrews 10:25).
Jesus said, "If anyone would come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow me" (Luke 9:23). True devotion requires sacrifice and commitment.

content.heading: 2. The Danger of a Shallow Relationship
paragraphs: If our pursuit of God is occasional, our faith will be weak.
* Shallow devotion leads to weak faith (Matthew 13:20-21).
* Inconsistent devotion leads to spiritual dryness (John 15:4-5).
* Neglecting devotion leads to distance from God (James 4:8).
Convenience-based devotion is like a plant with shallow roots—it cannot withstand trials. But when we prioritize time with God, our faith grows deep and strong.

content.heading: 3. Seeking God Wholeheartedly
paragraphs: God does not promise to reveal Himself to those who seek Him casually but to those who seek Him wholeheartedly.
1. Set a Fixed Time – Make devotion a priority, not an afterthought (Daniel 6:10).
2. Remove Distractions – Find a quiet place and give God your full attention (Matthew 6:6).
3. Engage Your Heart – Read, pray, and worship with intentionality, not just routine (Psalm 119:11).
God desires deep relationship, not just routine practice.

content.heading: Application: How Are You Seeking God?
paragraphs: Are you seeking God only when it is convenient, or do you pursue Him with all your heart?
Is your devotional life consistent and intentional, or occasional and shallow?
What steps can you take to make God your first priority every day?

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: "Lord, forgive me for seeking You only when it is easy. Teach me to desire You above all else. Help me to seek You with my whole heart and to make time with You a priority, not an option. Amen."

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Evaluate your daily routine. Identify one thing you can remove or adjust to prioritize time with God consistently.

content.heading: Final Thought
paragraphs: A faith of convenience will always be weak. A faith of commitment will always be strong.
Seek God with all your heart—He is worth it.

title: Thirsting for More: Broken Cisterns vs. Living Water
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: "For my people have committed two evils: they have forsaken me, the fountain of living waters, and hewed out cisterns for themselves, broken cisterns that can hold no water."

content.heading: Introduction: The Universal Thirst
paragraphs: Have you ever felt like no matter what you achieve, buy, or pursue, there's still an emptiness inside? The world offers many things that seem to promise satisfaction—success, relationships, pleasure, entertainment—but in the end, they leave us thirsting for more.

The prophet Jeremiah delivered this message during King Josiah's reign (627–609 BCE), a time of religious reform (2 Kings 22–23). God, through Jeremiah, brought a covenant lawsuit against Judah, accusing them of two sins:

1. They abandoned Yahweh, the "fountain of living waters." Flowing water in Scripture represents divine sustenance, holiness, and life. But Judah severed their covenant bond, choosing spiritual dryness over God's unending provision.

2. They turned to "broken cisterns that can hold no water." Instead of trusting in God, they relied on idolatry, foreign alliances (Egypt and Assyria), and self-reliance. These pursuits were as leaky as cracked reservoirs—incapable of security or fulfillment.

Though Josiah's reforms sought to eradicate idolatry, Jeremiah's message suggests their repentance was superficial—Judah's heart was still divided. Their paradox was tragic: they exchanged infinite grace for finite, crumbling substitutes.
This message remains painfully relevant today. We, too, turn to modern "broken cisterns," thinking they will satisfy, only to find ourselves spiritually drained.

content.heading: Point 1: Broken Cisterns – The Illusion of Satisfaction
paragraphs: Modern society offers many "cisterns" that seem to promise fulfillment, but they cannot hold water:

• Pornography & Sexual Immorality – Many turn to sexual pleasure to fill emotional or relational emptiness. While it offers momentary excitement, it often leads to addiction, guilt, and greater dissatisfaction. It cannot replace the intimacy and love that only Christ can provide.

• Social Media & Approval Seeking – The pursuit of likes, comments, and recognition can feel fulfilling at first, but it breeds comparison, anxiety, and an endless thirst for validation. True worth is found in Christ, not in the approval of people.
• Success & Workaholism – Achievements, promotions, and financial gains can seem satisfying, but no amount of success ever feels like "enough." Without Christ, our work remains an empty pursuit.

• Entertainment & Escapism – Movies, video games, social media scrolling—these can numb our pain for a while, but they do not address our deep longing for meaning and joy. Christ offers real peace, not just temporary distraction.
• Substance Abuse & Addictions – Alcohol, drugs, and unhealthy habits promise relief but only deepen the emptiness inside. They enslave rather than satisfy.
• Relationships & Romantic Love – Some seek fulfillment in relationships, believing that human love can complete them. But no person can fill the God-shaped void in our hearts.
These cisterns leak—they promise satisfaction but fail to hold water. They cannot truly quench our spiritual thirst.

content.heading: Point 2: Christ – The Fountain of Living Water
paragraphs: In contrast to these empty pursuits, Christ is a fountain—a never-ending source of true satisfaction. Jesus said in John 4:14:
"Whoever drinks the water I give them will never thirst. Indeed, the water I give them will become in them a spring of water welling up to eternal life."
Why Can Christ Meet Our Deepest Needs?
Unlike broken cisterns, Christ never runs dry because:
1. He is the Source of Life – Just as water is essential for physical life, Jesus is essential for spiritual life. Without Him, we remain spiritually dead in sin (John 7:37-38).
2. He Alone Can Satisfy the Soul – Everything else leaves us longing for more, but Jesus completes us. He offers lasting joy, not just temporary pleasure (Psalm 16:11).
3. He Gives Us True Security – Worldly things can be lost—money, relationships, achievements—but Christ never leaves or forsakes us (Hebrews 13:5).
How Does Christ Satisfy Our Deepest Needs?
1. Through His Presence – When we abide in Him, He fills our hearts with peace that surpasses understanding (Philippians 4:7).
2. Through His Word – The Scriptures nourish us, guide us, and remind us of His promises (Matthew 4:4).
3. Through the Holy Spirit – The Spirit dwells in us, producing love, joy, and peace that worldly pursuits cannot provide (Galatians 5:22-23).
4. Through His Sacrifice – On the cross, Jesus paid the price for our sin, making it possible for us to be reconciled to God. Only through Him can we find eternal satisfaction (John 6:35).
Rather than running after temporary satisfactions, we must learn to drink deeply from Christ—His Word, His presence, and His promises.

content.heading: Application: Where Are You Drinking From?
paragraphs: Ask yourself:
• Am I relying on temporary things to quench my thirst?
• Have I truly found satisfaction in Christ, or am I still searching?
• What broken cisterns in my life need to be abandoned so I can drink deeply from Christ?
If you've been drinking from broken cisterns, it's time to turn to the fountain of living water. Christ alone can satisfy your soul.

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: "Lord, I confess that I have sought satisfaction in things that cannot truly fulfill me. Help me to turn away from broken cisterns and drink deeply from You, the fountain of living water. Satisfy my soul with Your presence and love. Amen."

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Spend time in prayer today, asking God to reveal the broken cisterns in your life. Read John 6:35, where Jesus declares,
"I am the bread of life; whoever comes to me shall not hunger, and whoever believes in me shall never thirst."
Surrender your desires to Christ and ask Him to be your true source of satisfaction.

title: The Inescapable Reality of Death—And Christ's Victory Over It
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: "He is torn from the tent in which he trusted and is brought to the king of terrors."

content.heading: Introduction: Humanity's Fear of Death
paragraphs: Death is inevitable—no one can escape it. Rich or poor, powerful or weak, famous or forgotten—every human being will one day face death. It is the great equalizer, and yet, most people go through life avoiding the thought of it.

Ever since the fall of Adam, humanity has sought ways to push death out of our minds. Some seek distractions—pleasure, entertainment, career ambitions, relationships—while others put their hope in technology, medicine, or even denial (acting as though death won't come for them). But no matter how much we try to ignore it, death remains inevitable (Ecclesiastes 8:8).

Job 18:14 calls death "the king of terrors." Why? Because for those without Christ, death is terrifying—it represents the unknown, judgment, and separation from God. But the Gospel provides the only true answer.

content.heading: Point 1: Humanity's Failed Attempts to Escape Death
paragraphs: Throughout history, people have sought ways to avoid thinking about death and eternity.
1. The Pursuit of Pleasure – Many live for pleasure, entertainment, and indulgence, trying to distract themselves from the reality of death (Luke 12:19-20).
2. The Pursuit of Success – Some chase money, fame, or power, believing that achievements will give their lives meaning. But in the end, all accomplishments are left behind (Ecclesiastes 2:18-19).
3. Philosophical & Religious Schemes – Some try to redefine death by calling it a "natural part of life" or creating false beliefs about the afterlife to comfort themselves.
4. Scientific Efforts to Overcome Death – In our modern age, people hope that medical advancements, AI, or cryogenics will somehow extend life indefinitely. But no technology can prevent death.
No matter what scheme people invent, death still comes. And for those without Christ, it is truly the "king of terrors."

content.heading: Point 2: God's Judgment on Death – The Divine Enemy
paragraphs: But here's the Gospel's great revelation: God Himself has declared war on death.
In Hosea 13:14, God speaks of His judgment against death itself:
"I shall ransom them from the power of Sheol; I shall redeem them from Death. O Death, where are your plagues? O Sheol, where is your sting?"
This is not just poetic language—it is a declaration that God will defeat death itself.
In 1 Corinthians 15:54-57, Paul echoes Hosea's prophecy and proclaims its fulfillment:
"Death is swallowed up in victory. O death, where is your victory? O grave, where is your sting? ... Thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ."
God does not accept death as a natural part of life—He sees it as the enemy that must be destroyed (1 Corinthians 15:26). And He has accomplished this through Jesus Christ.

content.heading: Point 3: Christ's Victory Over Death
paragraphs: How did Christ conquer the "king of terrors"?

1. Through His Incarnation – Christ entered into our human experience, even suffering death Himself (Hebrews 2:14-15). He came to destroy the one who holds the power of death—the devil—and free those enslaved by the fear of death.
2. Through His Death on the Cross – Jesus bore the full penalty of sin (Romans 6:23), facing death head-on so that we would not have to fear judgment (Romans 8:1).
3. Through His Resurrection – The ultimate proof of victory! Christ rose from the dead (1 Corinthians 15:20), proving that death has been defeated and no longer holds the final word for believers.

4. Through His Promise of Eternal Life – Jesus said in John 11:25-26, "I am the resurrection and the life. Whoever believes in me, though he die, yet shall he live." Death is no longer a curse for believers—it is the doorway to eternal life with God.
Because of Christ, death is no longer the "king of terrors." For those who belong to Him, it is a defeated enemy.

content.heading: Point 4: How This Gospel Truth Shapes Our Lives
paragraphs: Since Christ has overcome death, how should we live?
1. We No Longer Fear Death – We do not live in anxiety about dying, because our future is secure in Christ (Philippians 1:21-23).
2. We Live with Purpose – Since life is short, we do not waste it on empty pursuits but live fully for God's glory (Ephesians 5:15-16).
3. We Proclaim the Gospel Boldly – People around us fear death but may not admit it. We must share the only message that brings hope—the Gospel of Jesus Christ (2 Timothy 1:10).
4. We Fix Our Eyes on Eternity – Instead of clinging to the things of this world, we set our hearts on the life to come (Colossians 3:1-2).
Christ's victory over death means we can live without fear, without regret, and with total confidence in our eternal future.

content.heading: Application: Are You Ready for Eternity?
paragraphs: • Are you avoiding thinking about death, or have you faced it with Gospel truth?
• Do you live each day for Christ, knowing that life is short?
• Are you helping others find the only true hope beyond the grave—Jesus Christ?
If your trust is in Christ, death is not your enemy—it is the gateway to eternal joy. If your trust is in anything else, now is the time to turn to the One who conquered the grave.

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: "Lord, I confess that I have often placed my hope in things that cannot save me. Thank You for sending Christ to defeat death and give me eternal life. Help me to live fearlessly, knowing that my security is in You. Amen."

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Read 1 Corinthians 15:50-58 and meditate on Christ's victory over death. If you struggle with fear of death, bring it before God in prayer, asking Him to help you rest in His promises.

title: Finding Worth in Christ—Overcoming Low Self-Esteem
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: “To the praise of the glory of His grace, by which He made us accepted in the Beloved.”
introduction: Searching for Worth in the Wrong Places

content.heading: Introduction: Searching for Worth in the Wrong Places
paragraphs: Many struggle with low self-esteem, feeling unworthy, insignificant, or unloved. The world tells us that our worth is found in:
• Achievements – “If I succeed, then I matter.”
• Appearance – “If I look good, I am valuable.”
• Approval – “If people like me, I have worth.”
• Performance – “If I do enough, God will love me.”

This self-focused search often leads to discouragement, anxiety, and insecurity. Even in the church, some believe that thinking too little of themselves is humility. But biblical humility is not thinking less of ourselves—it is thinking rightly about ourselves in light of who we are in Christ.
Instead of searching within ourselves for worth, the Bible points us to our true identity in Christ.

content.heading: Point 1: Our Worth Comes from God, Not Ourselves
paragraphs: Many look inward for self-worth, but the Bible directs us upward—to God.
1. We Are Created in God’s Image – Our worth is not based on talent, status, or beauty but on the fact that we bear His image (Genesis 1:27).
2. We Are Loved by God – Our identity is rooted in His love, not in how we feel about ourselves (Jeremiah 31:3; Romans 5:8).
3. We Are Accepted in Christ – Ephesians 1:6 declares that we are fully accepted by God—not because of our performance, but because of Jesus.
If we try to define ourselves apart from God, we will always feel lacking. But when we see ourselves as God sees us, our search for worth ends in His unchanging love.

content.heading: Point 2: The Danger of a Self-Focused View
paragraphs: The world’s solutions to low self-esteem focus on self-improvement, self-love, and self-empowerment. But the Bible warns that self-centered thinking leads us further from truth (Jeremiah 17:9).
1. Self-Exaltation Leads to Pride – Some try to fix insecurity by boosting self-confidence, but this often leads to pride and comparison (Proverbs 16:18).
2. Self-Doubt Leads to Defeat – Others remain trapped in self-condemnation, believing they are worthless, despite what God says.
3. True Healing Comes from Looking to Christ, Not Self – The more we focus on ourselves, the more we struggle. The more we fix our eyes on Jesus, the more we are transformed (Hebrews 12:2).
The Gospel is not about finding strength in ourselves but about finding sufficiency in Christ.

content.heading: Point 3: The Gospel’s Answer to Low Self-Esteem
paragraphs: Instead of fixing our gaze on ourselves, Scripture calls us to focus on Christ’s sufficiency.
1. Christ Defines Our Worth – Our identity is found in being God’s child, not in what we accomplish (John 1:12).
2. Christ’s Righteousness Covers Us – We don’t need to prove ourselves; Jesus has made us new (2 Corinthians 5:17, 21).
3. Christ Calls Us to Walk in Confidence, Not Fear – True confidence is not found in our abilities but in God’s power (2 Timothy 1:7).
Jesus does not say, “Believe in yourself.” He says, “Believe in Me.” Our worth is secure in Him.

content.heading: Point 4: Living in the Confidence of Christ
paragraphs: When we understand our identity in Christ, we no longer live in fear or insecurity. Instead, we live in freedom.
1. Stop Listening to the Lies – Reject the enemy’s whispers that say you are not enough (John 8:44).
2. Fill Your Mind with Truth – Meditate on Scriptures that declare who you are in Christ (Romans 12:2).
3. Live Boldly in God’s Grace – Stop striving for self-worth and rest in who God has made you to be (Ephesians 2:10).
Confidence does not come from thinking more of ourselves—it comes from knowing we are complete in Christ (Colossians 2:10).

content.heading: Application: Where Are You Looking for Worth?
paragraphs: Are you basing your worth on the world’s standards instead of God’s truth?
Are you focused on self-improvement rather than resting in Christ?
Are you living in fear and insecurity, forgetting that God has fully accepted you?
The solution is not better self-esteem—it is a Christ-centered identity.

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: “Lord, I confess that I have searched for worth in the wrong places. Help me to see myself as You see me—accepted, loved, and complete in Christ. Teach me to rest in Your truth and not in my own efforts. Amen.”

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Write down three biblical truths about your identity in Christ and read them daily. Replace negative thoughts with God’s Word.

content.heading: Final Thought
paragraphs: The world says, “Find your worth in yourself.”
God says, “Your worth is found in Me.”
Stop searching for identity in the wrong places—rest in the truth that you are fully loved and accepted in Christ.

title: No Middle Ground: The Gospel That Transforms
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: “For thus says the One who is high and lifted up, who inhabits eternity, whose name is Holy: ‘I dwell in the high and holy place, and also with him who is of a contrite and lowly spirit, to revive the spirit of the lowly, and to revive the heart of the contrite.’”
introduction: The Illusion of the Middle Ground

content.heading: Context of Isaiah 57:15
paragraphs: Isaiah 57 is part of a section where God rebukes Israel for their idolatry and spiritual unfaithfulness. The people had turned away from God, trusting in idols, human wisdom, and worldly alliances instead of the Lord. Because of their rebellion, they had separated themselves from His presence and were experiencing spiritual dryness.
However, Isaiah 57:15 presents both a warning and a promise. God declares where He dwells—only in two places:
1. In the high and holy place – This speaks of God’s transcendence, His absolute holiness, and His sovereignty over all creation.
2. With the contrite and lowly in spirit – Though He is exalted, He draws near to the humble and repentant to revive and restore them.

This verse shatters the illusion that we can find God on our own terms or in a lukewarm faith. There is no middle ground where God can be found—He is either approached in awe of His holiness or in brokenness and humility. The Gospel of Jesus Christ is the answer, lifting us up to God’s holiness and humbling us to true repentance.

content.heading: Introduction: The Illusion of the Middle Ground
paragraphs: Many people try to find God in a comfortable middle—where they can claim faith without full surrender, pursue holiness without forsaking sin, and trust in self-effort while still seeking God’s grace. But Isaiah 57:15 makes it clear:
• God dwells in the high and holy place—where He reigns in glory.
• God dwells with the contrite and lowly—those who come in humility.
There is no middle ground. The good news is that the Gospel transforms us—lifting us to worship in His holiness and humbling us to surrender in repentance.

content.heading: Point 1: Christ’s Sufficiency to Lift Us to God
paragraphs: Because of sin, we are separated from the high and holy place of God. Our best efforts and religious works cannot bridge the gap:
• Sinful man cannot stand before a holy God (Habakkuk 1:13).
• All have fallen short of His glory (Romans 3:23).
• Our righteousness is like filthy rags (Isaiah 64:6).
But Christ came to lift us up! The Gospel is the only way we can approach God:
• Jesus, the Son of God, descended from glory (Philippians 2:6-7).
• He lived the life of perfect holiness we could not.
• He died and rose to bring us into God’s presence (1 Peter 3:18).
Now, through faith in Christ, we are clothed in His righteousness (2 Corinthians 5:21) and have access to the high and holy place of God. We no longer strive to reach Him—He has made the way for us.

content.heading: Point 2: Christ’s Sufficiency to Humble and Revive Us
paragraphs: While Christ lifts us to God, He also humbles our hearts, breaking our pride and self-reliance.
• The cross reminds us that we cannot save ourselves (Ephesians 2:8-9).
• The Spirit convicts us of sin, leading us to godly sorrow and repentance (2 Corinthians 7:10).
• True transformation comes when we deny ourselves and follow Him (Luke 9:23).
Jesus is not found in the proud and self-sufficient but in the broken and contrite. When we surrender, He revives our hearts and fills us with new life.

content.heading: Point 3: The Gospel Transforms Us Completely
paragraphs: The Gospel does not allow for partial transformation. It calls us to leave the middle ground behind.
• We are no longer slaves to sin but alive in Christ (Romans 6:6-7).
• We are seated with Christ in heavenly places (Ephesians 2:6).
• We walk in newness of life (Romans 6:4).
Jesus is not just part of our life—He becomes our everything. The sufficiency of Christ means we are fully satisfied in Him, no longer seeking identity, hope, or purpose elsewhere.

content.heading: Application: Where Are You Standing?
paragraphs: • Are you trying to live in the middle, holding onto both God and the world?
• Have you fully embraced Christ’s sufficiency, allowing Him to lift you in holiness and humble you in repentance?
• Is your life truly transformed, or are you still resisting surrender?

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: “Lord, I confess that I have sought a middle ground where You cannot be found. I surrender my pride, my self-sufficiency, and my half-hearted devotion. Transform me by the power of the Gospel. Lift me by Your grace and humble me by Your Spirit. Let my life be fully Yours. Amen.”

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Examine your heart today. Are you standing in awe of God’s holiness? Are you humbling yourself before Him? Remove anything that keeps you in the middle ground and seek Him where He is truly found.

content.heading: Final Thought
paragraphs: God is found in the heights of His holiness and in the depths of our humility—but never in between. The Gospel lifts us and humbles us. Are you truly transformed?
